[ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('8e453edb-1c7a-4e61-bdf1-d27ecac8e7ff'), title='Will both of the following occur: (a) There be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120 and (b) The USA enter a second civil war before 2031?', body="Resolution Criteria\nThis question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met:\n(a) There is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.\n(b) All of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:\n- The Insurrection Act is invoked.\n- While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.\n- All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).\nFine Print\nFor condition (a), we'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\nThe stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.\nFor condition (b), any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.\nConflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.\nDeaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.\n", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2119, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('a233bea8-97cb-4acc-a792-d39607ab9380'), title='Will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?', body='Resolution Criteria\nNick Bostrom, philosopher and Founding Director of the Future of Humanity Institute at the University of Oxford, argues that only two events since the dawn of humanity have fundamentally changed the human condition: the Agricultural Revolution that took place approximately 10,000 years ago, and the Industrial Revolution which took place from roughly 1760-1840. Bostrom states the following:\n"So what kind of thing would count as a fundamental change in the human condition?\n"You could argue that if we look back over history, there has really only been two events that have fundamentally changed the human condition, the first being the Agricultural Revolution some 10,000 or 12,000 years ago in Mesopotamia, where we transitioned from being hunter-gatherers, small bands roaming around, to settling into cities, growing, domesticating crops and animals. With that you get social stratification, if there is a lot of grain, you could have a king or pharaoh who extracts the surplus, you can have standing armies, you can have war, you can have higher population densities, specialisation of labour, and from that point on, innovation grows much faster and population grows faster as well as a result.\n"The second fundamental change in the human condition, Industrial Revolution, where for the first time, you have the rate of economic and technological growth outstripping population growth, and so only when this happens can you have an increase in average income. Before that, there was technological growth and economic growth, but the economy grew 10%, the population grew 10%, everybody\'s still in a Malthusian condition."\nBostrom further argues that there are relatively few potential technologies that could have the same kind of impact, and that perhaps foremost among them is machine intelligence.\nThe kind of discontinuity in the human condition seen as a result of the agricultural and industrial revolutions is substantial; human civilisation became markedly more complex, acquired fundamentally new abilities, and the human experience became radically different after each of these events.\nThe question we ask here is: Before January 1 2100, will the human condition change fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions?\n"The human condition," for the purposes of this question, is the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality humanity has achieved at the civilisational level.\nThe discontinuity can be in either direction - though it seems improbable that Metaculus would continue to exist if humanity were to revert to a pre-industrial state.\nEvents that may occur this century, but which do not appear to represent a discontinuity of approximately the same degree as the agricultural and industrial revolutions, include (among other things) the establishment of bases or settlements on other bodies in the solar system, the achievement of modest to moderate life extension (e.g. an additional 10 to 30 years of life) or a significant but not radical increase in economic productivity.\nResolution\nIf at any time after the date of 2025-01-01 both the community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, the question resolves positively or negatively, respectively. With 20% probability, the question resolves according to a committee of 5 Metaculus admins, who will vote yes or no (not ambiguous), and will unmake their respective predictions so that they do not gain or lose points on the question.\nNote that the admins will be voting on whether the qualifying event has already happened, not whether they believe it will happen; for example, if the probability goes to 99% because a super-powerful AI seems immininent within 10 years, but it has not actually happened yet, the committee should unanimously vote no.\nIf the question has not resolved by January 1 2100, it resolves ambiguously.\n', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2099, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='metaculus', url='https://www.metaculus.com/questions/1646', metadata={'topics': [], 'background_info': ''}, resolution=None)]

messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant. I will give you a forecasting question with Yes/No answer. You should then give me the NEGATION of the question, i.e. the question that would be answered YES if the original question would be answered NO, and vice versa. Notes to keep in mind:\n- When negating compound questions, be careful to apply de Morgan\'s law correctly. The negation of (P OR Q) is (NOT P AND NOT Q). The negation of (P AND Q) is (NOT P OR NOT Q).\n- In a conditional question, do not negate the condition. E.g. \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be less than 15 degrees Celsius?\' should be negated to \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be 15 degrees Celsius or more?\'.\n- The negation of \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of X?\' is usually \'Will there be no proof/evidence/reports of X?\', not \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of not X?.\' This also applies to the resolution criteria: \'Resolves YES if there is proof/evidence reports of X\' should be negated to \'Resolves YES if there is no proof/evidence/reports of X\' unless explicit resolution criteria are given for the original question to resolve NO, in which case those explicit criteria should be given as the resolution criteria for the negated question.\n- If applicable, the different parts of the question should be negated one to one. For example the new title should be an negation of the original title. Body questions should be negations of the original body questions. Statements / background information would generally be kept the same.\n- Pay attention to correctly negate existential and universal quantifiers. For example, the negation of \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, exceed 1 trillion USD?\' is \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth never exceed 1 trillion USD before 2050?\', and NOT \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, not exceed 1 trillion USD?\'.\n- Make sure you retain ALL the information in the question title and body! You cannot discard a single relevant detail.\n - One type of question you may be given is a single choice from a multiple choice question. For example, you may be given \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. This is asking if Japan will recognize and legalize human cloning by 2030. You can negate this normally, i.e. \'Which of these countries will not legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. Such a question may also itself be a logical combination -- e.g. \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (UK, France, or Germany) is asking if any either of the UK, France, or Germany will legalize human cloning by 2030. Make sure to correctly negate such a combination with de Morgan\'s law.\n\n{"P":{"title":"Conditional on US life expectancy at birth for both sexes falling below 75 years before 2040, will there be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?","body":"Resolution Criteria for P:\\nThis question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) is less than 75 years, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question.\\n\\nResolution Criteria for Q:\\nThis question will resolve as Yes if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:\\nThree countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory\\nTwo countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.\\nThese conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.\\nAs with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway.\\n\\nSuppose the following is true: US life expectancy at birth for both sexes falls below 75 years before 2040. Then is it true that there will be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?"}}'}]

[ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('8e453edb-1c7a-4e61-bdf1-d27ecac8e7ff'), title='Will both of the following occur: (a) There be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120 and (b) The USA enter a second civil war before 2031?', body="Resolution Criteria\nThis question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met:\n(a) There is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.\n(b) All of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:\n- The Insurrection Act is invoked.\n- While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.\n- All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).\nFine Print\nFor condition (a), we'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\nThe stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.\nFor condition (b), any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.\nConflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.\nDeaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. It resolves negatively if there are proofs of either both A and B or both C and D. If neither event takes place before the resolution date of the question, the question resolves ambiguously\n', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2099, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='metaculus', url='https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8049', metadata={'topics': [], 'background_info': "The Navier-Stokes existence and smoothness conjecture is an important open problem in fluid dynamics and the theory of partial differential equations. It's been designated as one of the Clay Institute's Millennium Prize Problems in 2000 and there is a 1 million dollar bounty available for either proving or disproving the conjecture. In the official introduction to the problem here, the Clay Institute splits the problem into four statements A, B, C and D; and the problem is considered to have been settled if any one of them is proven.\nImportantly for this question, the statements A and C are about the Navier-Stokes equations defined on the noncompact space\nℝ\n3\n, while B and D are about the equations defined on the compact torus\n(ℝ/ℤ\n)\n3\n."}, resolution=None)]

Notes to keep in mind:\n- When negating compound questions, be careful to apply de Morgan\'s law correctly. The negation of (P OR Q) is (NOT P AND NOT Q). The negation of (P AND Q) is (NOT P OR NOT Q).\n- In a conditional question, do not negate the condition. E.g. \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be less than 15 degrees Celsius?\' should be negated to \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be 15 degrees Celsius or more?\'.\n- The negation of \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of X?\' is usually \'Will there be no proof/evidence/reports of X?\', not \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of not X?.\' This also applies to the resolution criteria: \'Resolves YES if there is proof/evidence reports of X\' should be negated to \'Resolves YES if there is no proof/evidence/reports of X\' unless explicit resolution criteria are given for the original question to resolve NO, in which case those explicit criteria should be given as the resolution criteria for the negated question.\n- If applicable, the different parts of the question should be negated one to one. For example the new title should be an negation of the original title. Body questions should be negations of the original body questions. Statements / background information would generally be kept the same.\n- Pay attention to correctly negate existential and universal quantifiers. For example, the negation of \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, exceed 1 trillion USD?\' is \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth never exceed 1 trillion USD before 2050?\', and NOT \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, not exceed 1 trillion USD?\'.\n- Make sure you retain ALL the information in the question title and body! You cannot discard a single relevant detail.\n - One type of question you may be given is a single choice from a multiple choice question. You can negate this normally, i.e. \'Which of these countries will not legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. Such a question may also itself be a logical combination -- e.g. \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (UK, France, or Germany) is asking if any either of the UK, France, or Germany will legalize human cloning by 2030. Make sure to correctly negate such a combination with de Morgan\'s law.\n\n{"P":{"title":"Will there be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120?","body":"Resolution Criteria\\nThis question will resolve positively if there is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.\\nFine Print\\nWe\'ll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\\nThe stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.\\n"}}'}]
{'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'response_model': <class 'static_checks.MiniInstantiator.Neg.OutputFormat_stripped'>, 'temperature': 0.5} Approx num tokens: 1351
options: {'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'temperature': 0.5, 'response_model': <class 'static_checks.MiniInstantiator.Neg.OutputFormat_stripped'>}
messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant. I will give you a forecasting question with Yes/No answer. You should then give me the NEGATION of the question, i.e. the question that would be answered YES if the original question would be answered NO, and vice versa. Notes to keep in mind:\n- When negating compound questions, be careful to apply de Morgan\'s law correctly. The negation of (P OR Q) is (NOT P AND NOT Q). The negation of (P AND Q) is (NOT P OR NOT Q).\n- In a conditional question, do not negate the condition. E.g. \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be less than 15 degrees Celsius?\' should be negated to \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be 15 degrees Celsius or more?\'.\n- The negation of \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of X?\' is usually \'Will there be no proof/evidence/reports of X?\', not \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of not X?.\' This also applies to the resolution criteria: \'Resolves YES if there is proof/evidence reports of X\' should be negated to \'Resolves YES if there is no proof/evidence/reports of X\' unless explicit resolution criteria are given for the original question to resolve NO, in which case those explicit criteria should be given as the resolution criteria for the negated question.\n- If applicable, the different parts of the question should be negated one to one. For example the new title should be an negation of the original title. Body questions should be negations of the original body questions. Statements / background information would generally be kept the same.\n- Pay attention to correctly negate existential and universal quantifiers. For example, the negation of \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, exceed 1 trillion USD?\' is \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth never exceed 1 trillion USD before 2050?\', and NOT \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, not exceed 1 trillion USD?\'.\n- Make sure you retain ALL the information in the question title and body! You cannot discard a single relevant detail.\n - One type of question you may be given is a single choice from a multiple choice question. For example, you may be given \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. This is asking if Japan will recognize and legalize human cloning by 2030. You can negate this normally, i.e. \'Which of these countries will not legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. Such a question may also itself be a logical combination -- e.g. \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (UK, France, or Germany) is asking if any either of the UK, France, or Germany will legalize human cloning by 2030. Make sure to correctly negate such a combination with de Morgan\'s law.\n\n{"P":{"title":"Will both of the following occur: (a) Europa will be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045, and (b) we will find life on Mars by 2050?","body":"Resolution Criteria\\nThis question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur:\\n(a) Humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this part will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this part will be Annulled. Note: extraterrestrial life must be (i) living currently and (ii) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.\\n(b) Prominent, highly respected scientific organizations announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050. If this has not happened before January 1, 2050, this part will resolve as No.\\n"}}'}]
---
[ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('8e453edb-1c7a-4e61-bdf1-d27ecac8e7ff'), title='Will both of the following occur: (a) There be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120 and (b) The USA enter a second civil war before 2031?', body="Resolution Criteria\nThis question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met:\n(a) There is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.\n(b) All of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:\n- The Insurrection Act is invoked.\n- While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.\n- All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).\nFine Print\nFor condition (a), we'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\nThe stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.\nFor condition (b), any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.\nConflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.\nDeaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.\n", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2119, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('2a7d30d9-7f8b-4220-82d0-4db8d5697643'), title="Will the identity of Bitcoin's founder, Satoshi Nakamoto, be revealed to the general public by 2025?", body='Resolution Criteria\nFew anonymous people--save maybe Banksy and Qanon--have generated as much press as "Satoshi Nakamoto", the maverick who developed bitcoin.\nHaven\'t heard of the man? Here\'s an executive summary per The Economist:\nON PAPER—or at least on the blockchain—Satoshi Nakamoto is one of the richest people on the planet.... But Mr Nakamoto, though actively involved with his brainchild in its early history, has been silent since 2011. An army of amateur detectives has been trying to work out who he really is, but there is frustratingly little to go on. While developing bitcoin he claimed to be male, in his late 30s and living in Japan, but even that information is suspect.\nWill we ever find out his true identity? Speculation abounds. (See here and here and here.) As noted above, Nakamoto is estimated to have more than a million bitcoins, mined very early on. So he\'d be worth well over $10Bn at current prices (as of launch), perhaps more. If he hasn\'t lost his thumb drive.\nQuestion resolves postive if Satoshi\'s true, corroborated identity is revealed to the world at large by April 5, 2025, his birthday. (Or is it??)\n', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2025, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='metaculus', url='https://www.metaculus.com/questions/1517', metadata={'topics': [], 'background_info': ''}, resolution=None)]

{'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'response_model': <class 'static_checks.MiniInstantiator.Neg.OutputFormat_stripped'>, 'temperature': 0.5} Approx num tokens: 1191
question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met:
(a) There is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.
(b) All of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:
- The Insurrection Act is invoked.
- While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.
- All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).
Fine Print
For condition (a), we'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):
The stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.
For condition (b), any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.
Conflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.
Deaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.

current_date: 2024-07-20 20:29:30.292261
kwargs: {'model': 'gpt-4o-mini'}
options: {'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'temperature': 0.5, 'response_model': <class 'common.datatypes.VerificationResult'>}
messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'I want you to help me validate if a forecasting question (as on sites like Metaculus / Manifold) is well defined. \nThe question will ask about an event in the future or past.\nThe fields are:\n- title: The title of the question.\n- body: The resolution criteria of the question.\n- resolution_date: The date when the outcome of the question will be decided.\n\nI want you to validate according to the following criteria:\n\n- The resolution date should be consistent with the question. In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. It is in December 2031, while the body says the question should resolve by January 2031.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 5:\ntitle: Will any member of Kanye West\'s family become the president of the United States by 2035?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West or any of his family members (including his wife, children, siblings and parents) is elected and... Show More\n\nresolution_date: 2035-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: There is a "Show More" instead of the end of the resolution criteria.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 6:\ntitle: Will a new strain of influenza virus with pandemic potential be identified by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new strain of influenza virus is identified that meets the following criteria: \n- The strain must be genetically distinct from previously identified strains, with genetic differences significant enough to be considered a new strain by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body.\n- The strain must have demonstrated the ability to cause human infection and have the potential for sustained human-to-human transmission.\n- The strain must be assessed by the WHO or a similar authoritative body as having pandemic potential, meaning it has a significant risk of causing widespread illness across multiple countries or continents.\nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution.\nresolution_date: 2030-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "Pandemic potential" is way too subjective; it is not a clearly objective threshold. \nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution." is not good because it is not clear on what exactly they should agree on.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 7:\ntitle: Will DeepMind develop an AI with the capability to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system that has been publicly recognized to significantly disrupt at least one major industry.  The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy. The resolution criteria must be quantifiable. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, the French national football team (senior, not youth or women\'s) has won either the FIFA World Cup or the UEFA European Championship.\nresolution_date: 2026-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is fine. The body is clear; there are multiple distinct pathways to resolution, but all are important for the question. The body includes a bit of background information that is not necessary for the question, but it is not harmful.\nvalid: True\n-----\n\ntitle: Will both of the following occur: (a) There be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120 and (b) The USA enter a second civil war before 2031?\nbody: Resolution Criteria\nThis question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met:\n(a) There is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.\n(b) All of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:\n- The Insurrection Act is invoked.\n- While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.\n- All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).\nFine Print\nFor condition (a), we\'ll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\nThe stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.\nFor condition (b), any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.\nConflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.\nDeaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.\n\nresolution_date: 2119-12-31 00:00:00+00:00\n'}]

messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant. I will give you a forecasting question with Yes/No answer. You should then give me the NEGATION of the question, i.e. the question that would be answered YES if the original question would be answered NO, and vice versa. Notes to keep in mind:\n- When negating compound questions, be careful to apply de Morgan\'s law correctly. The negation of (P OR Q) is (NOT P AND NOT Q). The negation of (P AND Q) is (NOT P OR NOT Q).\n- In a conditional question, do not negate the condition. E.g. \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be less than 15 degrees Celsius?\' should be negated to \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be 15 degrees Celsius or more?\'.\n- The negation of \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of X?\' is usually \'Will there be no proof/evidence/reports of X?\', not \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of not X?.\' This also applies to the resolution criteria: \'Resolves YES if there is proof/evidence reports of X\' should be negated to \'Resolves YES if there is no proof/evidence/reports of X\' unless explicit resolution criteria are given for the original question to resolve NO, in which case those explicit criteria should be given as the resolution criteria for the negated question.\n- If applicable, the different parts of the question should be negated one to one. For example the new title should be an negation of the original title. Body questions should be negations of the original body questions. Statements / background information would generally be kept the same.\n- Pay attention to correctly negate existential and universal quantifiers. For example, the negation of \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, exceed 1 trillion USD?\' is \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth never exceed 1 trillion USD before 2050?\', and NOT \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, not exceed 1 trillion USD?\'.\n- Make sure you retain ALL the information in the question title and body! You cannot discard a single relevant detail.\n - One type of question you may be given is a single choice from a multiple choice question. For example, you may be given \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. This is asking if Japan will recognize and legalize human cloning by 2030. You can negate this normally, i.e. \'Which of these countries will not legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. Such a question may also itself be a logical combination -- e.g. \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (UK, France, or Germany) is asking if any either of the UK, France, or Germany will legalize human cloning by 2030. Make sure to correctly negate such a combination with de Morgan\'s law.\n\n{"P":{"title":"Conditional on there being a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120, will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?","body":"Resolution Criteria for P:\\nThis question will resolve positively if there is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.\\nFine Print for P:\\nWe\'ll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\\nThe stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.\\n\\nResolution Criteria for Q:\\nThis question will resolve as Yes if all of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:\\nThe Insurrection Act is invoked.\\nWhile the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.\\nAll of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).\\nFine Print for Q:\\nAny conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.\\nConflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.\\nDeaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.\\n\\nSuppose the following is true: There is a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120. Then is the USA entering a second civil war before 2031?"}}'}]
question.body: Suppose the following is true: Humanity does not discover convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045, or does so after detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. Extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means. Then, will prominent, highly respected scientific organizations not announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050?

The resolution criteria must be quantifiable. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, the French national football team (senior, not youth or women\'s) has won either the FIFA World Cup or the UEFA European Championship.\nresolution_date: 2026-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is fine. The body is clear; there are multiple distinct pathways to resolution, but all are important for the question. The body includes a bit of background information that is not necessary for the question, but it is not harmful.\nvalid: True\n-----\n\ntitle: Conditional on Europa not being the first place humanity discovers extraterrestrial life before 2045, will we not find life on Mars by 2050?\nbody: Suppose the following is true: Humanity does not discover convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045, or does so after detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. Extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means. Then, will prominent, highly respected scientific organizations not announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050?\nresolution_date: 2050-12-31 00:00:00+00:00\n'}]
{'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'response_model': <class 'static_checks.MiniInstantiator.Neg.OutputFormat_stripped'>, 'temperature': 0.5} Approx num tokens: 1100
question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if humanity does not discover convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 or does so after detecting extraterrestrial life elsewhere in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly on Europa before January 1, 2045, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.
Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.

messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'I want you to help me validate if a forecasting question (as on sites like Metaculus / Manifold) is well defined. \nThe question will ask about an event in the future or past.\nThe fields are:\n- title: The title of the question.\n- body: The resolution criteria of the question.\n- resolution_date: The date when the outcome of the question will be decided.\n\nI want you to validate according to the following criteria:\n\n- The resolution date should be consistent with the question. In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. Show More\n\nresolution_date: 2035-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: There is a "Show More" instead of the end of the resolution criteria.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 6:\ntitle: Will a new strain of influenza virus with pandemic potential be identified by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new strain of influenza virus is identified that meets the following criteria: \n- The strain must be genetically distinct from previously identified strains, with genetic differences significant enough to be considered a new strain by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body.\n- The strain must have demonstrated the ability to cause human infection and have the potential for sustained human-to-human transmission.\n- The strain must be assessed by the WHO or a similar authoritative body as having pandemic potential, meaning it has a significant risk of causing widespread illness across multiple countries or continents.\nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution.\nresolution_date: 2030-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "Pandemic potential" is way too subjective; it is not a clearly objective threshold. \nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution." is not good because it is not clear on what exactly they should agree on.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 7:\ntitle: Will DeepMind develop an AI with the capability to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system that has been publicly recognized to significantly disrupt at least one major industry.  The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy. The resolution criteria must be quantifiable. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. question.body: Resolution Criteria for P:
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) is less than 75 years, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
This question will resolve as Yes if there is no armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory
Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway.

Suppose the following is true: US life expectancy at birth for both sexes falls below 75 years before 2040. Then is it true that there will be no global thermonuclear war by 2070?

question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if there is no period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.
Fine Print
We'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):
The stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.

Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. It is in December 2031, while the body says the question should resolve by January 2031.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 5:\ntitle: Will any member of Kanye West\'s family become the president of the United States by 2035?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West or any of his family members (including his wife, children, siblings and parents) is elected and... Show More\n\nresolution_date: 2035-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: There is a "Show More" instead of the end of the resolution criteria.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 6:\ntitle: Will a new strain of influenza virus with pandemic potential be identified by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new strain of influenza virus is identified that meets the following criteria: \n- The strain must be genetically distinct from previously identified strains, with genetic differences significant enough to be considered a new strain by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body.\n- The strain must have demonstrated the ability to cause human infection and have the potential for sustained human-to-human transmission.\n- The strain must be assessed by the WHO or a similar authoritative body as having pandemic potential, meaning it has a significant risk of causing widespread illness across multiple countries or continents.\nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution.\nresolution_date: 2030-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "Pandemic potential" is way too subjective; it is not a clearly objective threshold. \nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution." is not good because it is not clear on what exactly they should agree on.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 7:\ntitle: Will DeepMind develop an AI with the capability to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system that has been publicly recognized to significantly disrupt at least one major industry.  The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy. The resolution criteria must be quantifiable. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, the French national football team (senior, not youth or women\'s) has won either the FIFA World Cup or the UEFA European Championship.\nresolution_date: 2026-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is fine. The body is clear; there are multiple distinct pathways to resolution, but all are important for the question. The body includes a bit of background information that is not necessary for the question, but it is not harmful.\nvalid: True\n-----\n\ntitle: Will there be at least one open stock exchange in the US during every year up to 2120?\nbody: Resolution Criteria\nThis question will resolve positively if there is no period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.\nFine Print\nWe\'ll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\nThe stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.\nresolution_date: 2119-12-31 00:00:00+00:00\n'}]
{'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'response_model': <class 'common.datatypes.VerificationResult'>, 'temperature': 0.5} Approx num tokens: 2636
question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if neither of the following occur:
(a) At any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) is less than 75 years, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question.
(b) There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where neither of the following conditions are true:
- Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
- Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway.

Prompt: {"title":"Will Europa not be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045?","body":"Resolution Criteria\nThis question will resolve as Yes if humanity does not discover convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 or does so after detecting extraterrestrial life elsewhere in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly on Europa before January 1, 2045, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.\nNote: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.\n"}

options: {'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'temperature': 0.5, 'response_model': <class 'static_checks.MiniInstantiator.Neg.OutputFormat_stripped'>}
messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant. I will give you a forecasting question with Yes/No answer. You should then give me the NEGATION of the question, i.e. the question that would be answered YES if the original question would be answered NO, and vice versa. Notes to keep in mind:\n- When negating compound questions, be careful to apply de Morgan\'s law correctly. The negation of (P OR Q) is (NOT P AND NOT Q). The negation of (P AND Q) is (NOT P OR NOT Q).\n- In a conditional question, do not negate the condition. E.g. \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be less than 15 degrees Celsius?\' should be negated to \'If it rains tomorrow, will the temperature be 15 degrees Celsius or more?\'.\n- The negation of \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of X?\' is usually \'Will there be no proof/evidence/reports of X?\', not \'Will there be proof/evidence/reports of not X?.\' This also applies to the resolution criteria: \'Resolves YES if there is proof/evidence reports of X\' should be negated to \'Resolves YES if there is no proof/evidence/reports of X\' unless explicit resolution criteria are given for the original question to resolve NO, in which case those explicit criteria should be given as the resolution criteria for the negated question.\n- If applicable, the different parts of the question should be negated one to one. For example the new title should be an negation of the original title. Body questions should be negations of the original body questions. Statements / background information would generally be kept the same.\n- Pay attention to correctly negate existential and universal quantifiers. For example, the negation of \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, exceed 1 trillion USD?\' is \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth never exceed 1 trillion USD before 2050?\', and NOT \'Will Elon Musk\'s net worth, at any point before 2050, not exceed 1 trillion USD?\'.\n- Make sure you retain ALL the information in the question title and body! You cannot discard a single relevant detail.\n - One type of question you may be given is a single choice from a multiple choice question. For example, you may be given \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. This is asking if Japan will recognize and legalize human cloning by 2030. You can negate this normally, i.e. \'Which of these countries will not legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. Such a question may also itself be a logical combination -- e.g. \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (UK, France, or Germany) is asking if any either of the UK, France, or Germany will legalize human cloning by 2030. Make sure to correctly negate such a combination with de Morgan\'s law.\n\n{"P":{"title":"Will both of the following occur: (a) There be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120 and (b) The USA enter a second civil war before 2031?","body":"Resolution Criteria\\nThis question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met:\\n(a) There is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.\\n(b) All of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:\\n- The Insurrection Act is invoked.\\n- While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.\\n- All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).\\nFine Print\\nFor condition (a), we\'ll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\\nThe stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.\\nFor condition (b), any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.\\nConflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.\\nDeaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.\\n"}}'}]
question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if at least one of the following occurs:
(a) Humanity does not discover convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 or does so after detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this part will resolve as Yes. If extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this part will resolve as No. Note: extraterrestrial life must be (i) living currently and (ii) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.
(b) Prominent, highly respected scientific organizations do not announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050. If this has happened before January 1, 2050, this part will resolve as Yes.

The body is clear; there are multiple distinct pathways to resolution, but all are important for the question. The body includes a bit of background information that is not necessary for the question, but it is not harmful.\nvalid: True\n-----\n\ntitle: Will at least one of the following occur: (a) Europa will not be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045, or (b) we will not find life on Mars by 2050?\nbody: Resolution Criteria\nThis question will resolve as Yes if at least one of the following occurs:\n(a) Humanity does not discover convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 or does so after detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this part will resolve as Yes. If extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this part will resolve as No. Note: extraterrestrial life must be (i) living currently and (ii) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.\n(b) Prominent, highly respected scientific organizations do not announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050. If this has happened before January 1, 2050, this part will resolve as Yes.\nresolution_date: 2050-12-31 00:00:00+00:00\n'}]

question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extra terrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.
Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.

messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'I want you to help me validate if a forecasting question (as on sites like Metaculus / Manifold) is well defined. \nThe question will ask about an event in the future or past.\nThe fields are:\n- title: The title of the question.\n- body: The resolution criteria of the question.\n- resolution_date: The date when the outcome of the question will be decided.\n\nI want you to validate according to the following criteria:\n\n- The resolution date should be consistent with the question. In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. Show More\n\nresolution_date: 2035-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: There is a "Show More" instead of the end of the resolution criteria.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 6:\ntitle: Will a new strain of influenza virus with pandemic potential be identified by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new strain of influenza virus is identified that meets the following criteria: \n- The strain must be genetically distinct from previously identified strains, with genetic differences significant enough to be considered a new strain by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body.\n- The strain must have demonstrated the ability to cause human infection and have the potential for sustained human-to-human transmission.\n- The strain must be assessed by the WHO or a similar authoritative body as having pandemic potential, meaning it has a significant risk of causing widespread illness across multiple countries or continents.\nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution.\nresolution_date: 2030-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "Pandemic potential" is way too subjective; it is not a clearly objective threshold. \nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution." is not good because it is not clear on what exactly they should agree on.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 7:\ntitle: Will DeepMind develop an AI with the capability to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system that has been publicly recognized to significantly disrupt at least one major industry.  The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy.
