question.body: Suppose the following is true: Humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045, and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. Extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means. Then, will prominent, highly respected scientific organizations announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050?

messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'I want you to help me validate if a forecasting question (as on sites like Metaculus / Manifold) is well defined. \nThe question will ask about an event in the future or past.\nThe fields are:\n- title: The title of the question.\n- body: The resolution criteria of the question.\n- resolution_date: The date when the outcome of the question will be decided.\n\nI want you to validate according to the following criteria:\n\n- The resolution date should be consistent with the question. In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. It is in December 2031, while the body says the question should resolve by January 2031.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 5:\ntitle: Will any member of Kanye West\'s family become the president of the United States by 2035?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West or any of his family members (including his wife, children, siblings and parents) is elected and... Show More\n\nresolution_date: 2035-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: There is a "Show More" instead of the end of the resolution criteria.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 6:\ntitle: Will a new strain of influenza virus with pandemic potential be identified by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new strain of influenza virus is identified that meets the following criteria: \n- The strain must be genetically distinct from previously identified strains, with genetic differences significant enough to be considered a new strain by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body.\n- The strain must have demonstrated the ability to cause human infection and have the potential for sustained human-to-human transmission.\n- The strain must be assessed by the WHO or a similar authoritative body as having pandemic potential, meaning it has a significant risk of causing widespread illness across multiple countries or continents.\nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution.\nresolution_date: 2030-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "Pandemic potential" is way too subjective; it is not a clearly objective threshold. \nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution." is not good because it is not clear on what exactly they should agree on.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 7:\ntitle: Will DeepMind develop an AI with the capability to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system that has been publicly recognized to significantly disrupt at least one major industry.  The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy. The resolution criteria must be quantifiable. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, the French national football team (senior, not youth or women\'s) has won either the FIFA World Cup or the UEFA European Championship.\nresolution_date: 2026-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is fine. The body is clear; there are multiple distinct pathways to resolution, but all are important for the question. The body includes a bit of background information that is not necessary for the question, but it is not harmful.\nvalid: True\n-----\n\ntitle: Conditional on Europa being the first place humanity discovers extraterrestrial life before 2045, will we find life on Mars by 2050?\nbody: Suppose the following is true: Humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045, and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. Extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means. Then, will prominent, highly respected scientific organizations announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050?\nresolution_date: 2050-12-31 00:00:00+00:00\n'}]

An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question

In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. question.body: Criteria for determining the outcome of P:
This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if there exists a stretch of at least 12 uninterrupted months before the conclusion of 2120 during which no public stock exchanges in the US are available for trading.
Additional details for P:
We will refer to the definition of stock market/exchange as outlined on Investopedia (archive):
The stock market encompasses the various markets and exchanges where the regular buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly traded companies occur.

Criteria for determining the outcome of Q:
This inquiry will be considered a Yes if all the following conditions are satisfied before January 1, 2031:
The Insurrection Act is activated.
During the activation of the Insurrection Act, there are at least 500 fatalities within a 6-month timeframe due to armed confrontations between US citizens and a segment of the US military, national guard, or in clashes among such entities.
All of these fatalities happen in one or more US states (including DC).
Additional details for Q:
Any confrontations involving the US military and foreign armed forces will not be factored into this question. Confrontations between the US military and US citizens, potentially aided by other nations with weaponry or resources, will be included.
Clashes involving civilians and local law enforcement will be excluded unless there are active military forces in the area providing mutual assistance.
Fatalities will be counted across all states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. Newly admitted states will be included, while states that secede or are removed will not. Suicides will not be included in the death toll.

question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will be considered Yes if both of the following conditions are met:
(a) Convincing evidence of life is discovered on Europa by humanity prior to January 1, 2045, and this discovery occurs before any other extraterrestrial life is detected in the universe. If credible extraterrestrial life is found elsewhere before it is found on Europa, this component will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is identified before 2045, this component will be Annulled. Note: the extraterrestrial life must be (i) currently alive and (ii) not likely to have come from contamination by Earth spacecraft. This allows for the possibility of life that may have been transported from Earth through other natural means.
(b) Renowned and respected scientific organizations declare that unambiguous evidence of either current or past life on Mars has been found, independent of any life that may have been transported from Earth through human missions, before January 1, 2050. If this declaration has not occurred before January 1, 2050, this component will resolve as No.

In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. It is in December 2031, while the body says the question should resolve by January 2031.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 5:\ntitle: Will any member of Kanye West\'s family become the president of the United States by 2035?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West or any of his family members (including his wife, children, siblings and parents) is elected and... Show More\n\nresolution_date: 2035-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: There is a "Show More" instead of the end of the resolution criteria.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 6:\ntitle: Will a new strain of influenza virus with pandemic potential be identified by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new strain of influenza virus is identified that meets the following criteria: \n- The strain must be genetically distinct from previously identified strains, with genetic differences significant enough to be considered a new strain by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body.\n- The strain must have demonstrated the ability to cause human infection and have the potential for sustained human-to-human transmission.\n- The strain must be assessed by the WHO or a similar authoritative body as having pandemic potential, meaning it has a significant risk of causing widespread illness across multiple countries or continents.\nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution.\nresolution_date: 2030-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "Pandemic potential" is way too subjective; it is not a clearly objective threshold. \nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution." is not good because it is not clear on what exactly they should agree on.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 7:\ntitle: Will DeepMind develop an AI with the capability to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system that has been publicly recognized to significantly disrupt at least one major industry.  The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy. The resolution criteria must be quantifiable. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, the French national football team (senior, not youth or women\'s) has won either the FIFA World Cup or the UEFA European Championship.\nresolution_date: 2026-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is fine. The body is clear; there are multiple distinct pathways to resolution, but all are important for the question. The body includes a bit of background information that is not necessary for the question, but it is not harmful.\nvalid: True\n-----\n\ntitle: Will humanity first find extraterrestrial life on Europa before 2045 and also discover life on Mars by 2050?\nbody: Resolution Criteria\nThis question will be considered Yes if both of the following conditions are met:\n(a) Convincing evidence of life is discovered on Europa by humanity prior to January 1, 2045, and this discovery occurs before any other extraterrestrial life is detected in the universe. If credible extraterrestrial life is found elsewhere before it is found on Europa, this component will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is identified before 2045, this component will be Annulled. Note: the extraterrestrial life must be (i) currently alive and (ii) not likely to have come from contamination by Earth spacecraft. This allows for the possibility of life that may have been transported from Earth through other natural means.\n(b) Renowned and respected scientific organizations declare that unambiguous evidence of either current or past life on Mars has been found, independent of any life that may have been transported from Earth through human missions, before January 1, 2050. If this declaration has not occurred before January 1, 2050, this component will resolve as No.\nresolution_date: 2050-12-31 00:00:00+00:00\n'}]

question.body: Resolution Criteria for P:
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) is less than 75 years, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
This question will resolve as Yes if there is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:
Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory
Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.
These conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.
As with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway.

Suppose the following is true: US life expectancy at birth for both sexes falls below 75 years before 2040. Then is it true that there will be a global thermonuclear war by 2070?

In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant. I will give you a forecasting question with Yes/No answer. You should then give me a paraphrased version of the question that expresses the same underlying concept. The question should be as different as possible from the original question, while still meaning the exact same thing. Use synonyms, etc. Notes:\n\n - Make sure to retain all information in the question title and body! Paraphrase, but don\'t discard the essential meaning. This is very important.\n - Something to note: you cannot rephrase P to \'Do you think that P?\', \'Is P likely?\' or \'Will there be evidence of P?\'. These are not paraphrases, they mean different things (something may be likely and not happen, etc.).\n\n{"P":{"title":"Will both of the following occur: (a) There be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120 and (b) The USA enter a second civil war before 2031?","body":"Resolution Criteria\\nThis question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met:\\n(a) There is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.\\n(b) All of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:\\n- The Insurrection Act is invoked.\\n- While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.\\n- All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).\\nFine Print\\nFor condition (a), we\'ll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\\nThe stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.\\nFor condition (b), any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.\\nConflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.\\nDeaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.\\n"}}'}]

In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. It is in December 2031, while the body says the question should resolve by January 2031.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 5:\ntitle: Will any member of Kanye West\'s family become the president of the United States by 2035?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West or any of his family members (including his wife, children, siblings and parents) is elected and... Show More\n\nresolution_date: 2035-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: There is a "Show More" instead of the end of the resolution criteria.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 6:\ntitle: Will a new strain of influenza virus with pandemic potential be identified by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new strain of influenza virus is identified that meets the following criteria: \n- The strain must be genetically distinct from previously identified strains, with genetic differences significant enough to be considered a new strain by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body.\n- The strain must have demonstrated the ability to cause human infection and have the potential for sustained human-to-human transmission.\n- The strain must be assessed by the WHO or a similar authoritative body as having pandemic potential, meaning it has a significant risk of causing widespread illness across multiple countries or continents.\nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution.\nresolution_date: 2030-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "Pandemic potential" is way too subjective; it is not a clearly objective threshold. \nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution." is not good because it is not clear on what exactly they should agree on.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 7:\ntitle: Will DeepMind develop an AI with the capability to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system that has been publicly recognized to significantly disrupt at least one major industry.  The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy. The resolution criteria must be quantifiable. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, the French national football team (senior, not youth or women\'s) has won either the FIFA World Cup or the UEFA European Championship.\nresolution_date: 2026-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is fine. The body is clear; there are multiple distinct pathways to resolution, but all are important for the question. The body includes a bit of background information that is not necessary for the question, but it is not harmful.\nvalid: True\n-----\n\ntitle: Will we detect an exoplanet atmosphere with >5% oxygen atmosphere before 2030?\nbody: Resolution Criteria\nThis question will resolve as Yes if any exoplanet with >5% O2 atmosphere is found before January 1, 2030\nresolution_date: 2029-12-31 00:00:00+00:00\n'}]
{'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'response_model': <class 'common.datatypes.VerificationResult'>, 'temperature': 0.5} Approx num tokens: 2853
question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'I want you to help me validate if a forecasting question (as on sites like Metaculus / Manifold) is well defined. \nThe question will ask about an event in the future or past.\nThe fields are:\n- title: The title of the question.\n- body: The resolution criteria of the question.\n- resolution_date: The date when the outcome of the question will be decided.\n\nI want you to validate according to the following criteria:\n\n- The resolution date should be consistent with the question. In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.

Prompt: {"title":"Will humanity first find extraterrestrial life on Europa before 2045 and also discover life on Mars by 2050?","body":"Resolution Criteria\nThis question will be considered Yes if both of the following conditions are met:\n(a) Convincing evidence of life is discovered on Europa by humanity prior to January 1, 2045, and this discovery occurs before any other extraterrestrial life is detected in the universe. If credible extraterrestrial life is found elsewhere before it is found on Europa, this component will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is identified before 2045, this component will be Annulled. Note: the extraterrestrial life must be (i) currently alive and (ii) not likely to have come from contamination by Earth spacecraft. This allows for the possibility of life that may have been transported from Earth through other natural means.\n(b) Renowned and respected scientific organizations declare that unambiguous evidence of either current or past life on Mars has been found, independent of any life that may have been transported from Earth through human missions, before January 1, 2050. If this declaration has not occurred before January 1, 2050, this component will resolve as No."}

messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.I will give you two forecasting questions with Yes/No answers. You should then give me the logical AND of these two questions, i.e. the question that would be answered YES if BOTH questions are answered YES, and NO otherwise. Notes:\n\n - Your response should be as clear as possible, since the words \'and\' and \'or\' are used ambiguously in natural language. For example, \'Will P happen and will Q happen? is usually confusing, as it sounds like you are asking two questions. Instead, if there is any chance of confusion, you should give me something like: Will both of the following occur: (a) and P (b) Q?\n\n - When the questions allow for a simple rephrasing or factorization (e.g. using words like \'respectively\', \'both\' or \'either\'), go for it.\n - If one or both of the given questions is already a logical combination of questions, join them in the most natural way possible. E.g. \n    - combine ((P1 AND P2) AND Q) how you would combine (P1 AND P2 AND Q)\n    - ((P1 OR P2) AND Q) might have to be combined as something like: Will BOTH of the following occur: (1) EITHER of the following occurs: (a) P1 OR (b) P2 (2) Q. Unless a more natural formulation exists.\n - Be careful when combining conditional expressions (which often have words like \'given\' and \'if\'). \'(Given A then P) AND (Given B then Q) should be combined as \'Given (A AND B) then (P AND Q)\'. \n - When only one of the questions is conditional, the combined question should be conditional. i.e. \'(Given A then P) AND Q\' should be combined as \'Given A then (P AND Q)\'.\n - Most importantly: make sure you retain ALL the information in the question bodies from BOTH base questions! You cannot discard a single relevant detail. All this is for an experiment to test the logical consistency of forecasters: The combined question you give will be handed to the forecasters without having seen the base questions, so it is critical that all the information in the base questions be included in your logical combination; the resolution criterion for each component should be neatly and clearly provided.\n - Also, make sure that the title is self-sufficient independent of the body, i.e. is a question that can be meaningfully answered without looking at the body. So you CANNOT give me a question title like \'Is the following true?\' or \'What will happen if the following happens?\'\n - One type of question you may be given is a single choice from a multiple choice question. For example, you may be given \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. This is asking if Japan will recognize and legalize human cloning by 2030. Such a question may also itself be a logical combination -- e.g. \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (UK, France, or Germany) is asking if any either of the UK, France, or Germany will legalize human cloning by 2030. Make sure to correctly combine such combinations as previously described.\n\n{"P":{"title":"Will Europa be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045?","body":"Resolution Criteria\\nThis question will resolve as Yes if humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extra terrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.\\nNote: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.\\n"},"Q":{"title":"Will we detect an exoplanet atmosphere with >5% oxygen atmosphere before 2030?","body":"Resolution Criteria\\nThis question will resolve as Yes if any exoplanet with >5% O2 atmosphere is found before January 1, 2030"}}'}]

question.body: Resolution Criteria
The COVID-19 outbreak in China has been rife with allegations of misrepresentation by Chinese government officials. These began at the local level, where officials in Hubei province potentially under-reported the magnitude of the outbreak in early January to Chinese central government authorities. A public health worker famously released a video around January 26 claiming that at that time, at least 90,000 cases had occurred--at the time the Chinese government was reporting fewer than 2000 infections. Since then, the insufficiently-inclusive strategy of counting only persons with laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID-19 depressed the counts of probable cases. And the patterns of growth in the official counts follow an unexpected distribution, implying the counts may be generated by a model which doesn't accurately represent the dynamics of the disease's spread through the population.
This latter allegation is perhaps the most important and severe, as it means that estimations of epidemiological characteristics based on Chinese data may lead to public health interventions which do not reflect the reality of the viral spread. For example, if the R_0 (the average number of people an infected person will pass the virus along to) is underestimated, it may lead to insufficiently aggressive strategies for reducing the propagation of the virus across the globe. However, overestimating it could lead to overly-aggressive quarantining strategies, hobbling international commerce. Getting a proper assessment of the epidemiological dynamics is critical to devising the appropriate public health response.
Will at least two public health agencies publicly accuse the Chinese government of deliberately misrepresenting the number of COVID-19 infections before 2025?
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, at least two of the public health agencies listed below claim that it is more likely than not that the Chinese government deliberately lied about, fabricated, or misrepresented case or death numbers. If an agency claims that the numbers were flawed, but does not go as far as to suggest deliberate lying or misrepresentation, this will not count. For the purpose of this question, we consider only statements by the following public health agencies:
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (including the Epidemic Intelligence Service)
The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (including the Health Threat Unit)
World Health Organization
The Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention
The Centre for Health Protection
Robert Koch Institute
The National Institute of Infectious Diseases
Public Health England
The National Centre for Infectious Diseases
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Korea
The Public Health Agency of Canada
In case multiple subdivisions of any of the above agencies make assessments that China more likely than not lied about case or death numbers, these will only count as single accusation made by a single agency.
The relevant assessments will count if they are judged by Metaculus to broadly state that it is more likely than not that the Chinese government deliberately did lie about, fabricate, or misrepresent case or death counts.
This question has a short-fuse sister.

messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'I want you to help me validate if a forecasting question (as on sites like Metaculus / Manifold) is well defined. \nThe question will ask about an event in the future or past.\nThe fields are:\n- title: The title of the question.\n- body: The resolution criteria of the question.\n- resolution_date: The date when the outcome of the question will be decided.\n\nI want you to validate according to the following criteria:\n\n- The resolution date should be consistent with the question. In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. It is in December 2031, while the body says the question should resolve by January 2031.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 5:\ntitle: Will any member of Kanye West\'s family become the president of the United States by 2035?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West or any of his family members (including his wife, children, siblings and parents) is elected and... Show More\n\nresolution_date: 2035-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: There is a "Show More" instead of the end of the resolution criteria.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 6:\ntitle: Will a new strain of influenza virus with pandemic potential be identified by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new strain of influenza virus is identified that meets the following criteria: \n- The strain must be genetically distinct from previously identified strains, with genetic differences significant enough to be considered a new strain by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body.\n- The strain must have demonstrated the ability to cause human infection and have the potential for sustained human-to-human transmission.\n- The strain must be assessed by the WHO or a similar authoritative body as having pandemic potential, meaning it has a significant risk of causing widespread illness across multiple countries or continents.\nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution.\nresolution_date: 2030-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "Pandemic potential" is way too subjective; it is not a clearly objective threshold. \nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution." is not good because it is not clear on what exactly they should agree on.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 7:\ntitle: Will DeepMind develop an AI with the capability to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system that has been publicly recognized to significantly disrupt at least one major industry.  The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy. The resolution criteria must be quantifiable. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, the French national football team (senior, not youth or women\'s) has won either the FIFA World Cup or the UEFA European Championship.\nresolution_date: 2026-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is fine. question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if there is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.
Fine Print
We'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):
The stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.

{'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'response_model': <class 'static_checks.MiniInstantiator.And.OutputFormat_stripped'>, 'temperature': 0.5} Approx num tokens: 1335
question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur:
(a) Humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this part will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this part will be Annulled. Note: extraterrestrial life must be (i) living currently and (ii) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.
(b) Prominent, highly respected scientific organizations announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050. If this has not happened before January 1, 2050, this part will resolve as No.

current_date: 2024-07-20 20:30:01.888938
kwargs: {'model': 'gpt-4o-mini'}

In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. It is in December 2031, while the body says the question should resolve by January 2031.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 5:\ntitle: Will any member of Kanye West\'s family become the president of the United States by 2035?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West or any of his family members (including his wife, children, siblings and parents) is elected and... Show More\n\nresolution_date: 2035-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: There is a "Show More" instead of the end of the resolution criteria.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 6:\ntitle: Will a new strain of influenza virus with pandemic potential be identified by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new strain of influenza virus is identified that meets the following criteria: \n- The strain must be genetically distinct from previously identified strains, with genetic differences significant enough to be considered a new strain by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body.\n- The strain must have demonstrated the ability to cause human infection and have the potential for sustained human-to-human transmission.\n- The strain must be assessed by the WHO or a similar authoritative body as having pandemic potential, meaning it has a significant risk of causing widespread illness across multiple countries or continents.\nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution.\nresolution_date: 2030-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "Pandemic potential" is way too subjective; it is not a clearly objective threshold. \nIn the absence of a formal declaration by the WHO or a similar authoritative body, a consensus among at least three leading infectious disease research institutions will be considered sufficient for resolution." is not good because it is not clear on what exactly they should agree on.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 7:\ntitle: Will DeepMind develop an AI with the capability to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence (AI) system that has been publicly recognized to significantly disrupt at least one major industry.  The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. The resolution will rely on reports and analyses from the specified industry sources published by December 31, 2030. In the absence of clear industry consensus, a panel of experts from the affected industry may be consulted to determine the resolution.\n\n->\n\nreasoning: "to significantly disrupt at least one major industry by 2030" is too fuzzy. The resolution criteria must be quantifiable. "20%% increase in efficiency or productivity" is clearly not measurable.\nIn addition, we do not want multiple distinct pathways to resolution in a question where it is not important there are multiple pathways.\nHere, we have both the market share and "a comparable metric of impact" as resolution criteria, and notwithstanding the fact that impact is not defined clearly, we should not have both.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 8:\ntitle: Will France win any major football tournament by 2026?\nbody: France has last won the FIFA World Cup in 2018. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, the French national football team (senior, not youth or women\'s) has won either the FIFA World Cup or the UEFA European Championship.\nresolution_date: 2026-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is fine. The body is clear; there are multiple distinct pathways to resolution, but all are important for the question. The body includes a bit of background information that is not necessary for the question, but it is not harmful.\nvalid: True\n-----\n\ntitle: Will both of the following occur: (a) Europa will be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045, and (b) we will find life on Mars by 2050?\nbody: Resolution Criteria\nThis question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur:\n(a) Humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this part will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this part will be Annulled. Note: extraterrestrial life must be (i) living currently and (ii) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.\n(b) Prominent, highly respected scientific organizations announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050. If this has not happened before January 1, 2050, this part will resolve as No.\n\nresolution_date: 2050-12-31 00:00:00+00:00\n'}]

messages: [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are a helpful assistant.I will give you two forecasting questions with Yes/No answers. You should then give me the logical AND of these two questions, i.e. the question that would be answered YES if BOTH questions are answered YES, and NO otherwise. Notes:\n\n - Your response should be as clear as possible, since the words \'and\' and \'or\' are used ambiguously in natural language. For example, \'Will P happen and will Q happen? is usually confusing, as it sounds like you are asking two questions. Instead, if there is any chance of confusion, you should give me something like: Will both of the following occur: (a) and P (b) Q?\n\n - When the questions allow for a simple rephrasing or factorization (e.g. using words like \'respectively\', \'both\' or \'either\'), go for it.\n - If one or both of the given questions is already a logical combination of questions, join them in the most natural way possible. E.g. \n    - combine ((P1 AND P2) AND Q) how you would combine (P1 AND P2 AND Q)\n    - ((P1 OR P2) AND Q) might have to be combined as something like: Will BOTH of the following occur: (1) EITHER of the following occurs: (a) P1 OR (b) P2 (2) Q. Unless a more natural formulation exists.\n - Be careful when combining conditional expressions (which often have words like \'given\' and \'if\'). \'(Given A then P) AND (Given B then Q) should be combined as \'Given (A AND B) then (P AND Q)\'. \n - When only one of the questions is conditional, the combined question should be conditional. i.e. \'(Given A then P) AND Q\' should be combined as \'Given A then (P AND Q)\'.\n - Most importantly: make sure you retain ALL the information in the question bodies from BOTH base questions! You cannot discard a single relevant detail. All this is for an experiment to test the logical consistency of forecasters: The combined question you give will be handed to the forecasters without having seen the base questions, so it is critical that all the information in the base questions be included in your logical combination; the resolution criterion for each component should be neatly and clearly provided.\n - Also, make sure that the title is self-sufficient independent of the body, i.e. is a question that can be meaningfully answered without looking at the body. So you CANNOT give me a question title like \'Is the following true?\' or \'What will happen if the following happens?\'\n - One type of question you may be given is a single choice from a multiple choice question. For example, you may be given \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (Japan)\'. This is asking if Japan will recognize and legalize human cloning by 2030. Such a question may also itself be a logical combination -- e.g. \'Which of these countries will legalize human cloning by 2030? (UK, France, or Germany) is asking if any either of the UK, France, or Germany will legalize human cloning by 2030. Make sure to correctly combine such combinations as previously described.\n\n{"P":{"title":"Will both of the following occur: (a) US life expectancy at birth for both sexes fall below 75 years before 2040 and (b) a global thermonuclear war by 2070?","body":"Resolution Criteria\\nThis question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur:\\n(a) At any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) is less than 75 years, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question.\\n(b) There is an armed conflict before January 1, 2070 where either of the following conditions are true:\\n- Three countries each detonate at least 10 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.\\n- Two countries each detonate at least 50 nuclear devices of at least 10 kiloton yield outside of their own territory.\\nThese conditions are chosen to set aside a two-party regional nuclear war, say between India and Pakistan, or Israel and an adversary, or the UK and France, as disastrous as that would be.\\nAs with many questions with a positive-resolution condition that may preclude being awarded points on Metaculus, predictors are enjoined to predict in good faith, as points will not be awarded until 2070 anyway.\\n"},"Q":{"title":"Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?","body":"Resolution Criteria\\nThis question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.\\n(Note that 1880 isn\'t exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)\\nData for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.\\nThe last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data\\n"}}'}]

Confrontations between the US military and US citizens, potentially aided by other nations with weaponry or resources, will be included.\nClashes involving civilians and local law enforcement will be excluded unless there are active military forces in the area providing mutual assistance.\nFatalities will be counted across all states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. Newly admitted states will be included, while states that secede or are removed will not. Suicides will not be included in the death toll."}

question.body: Resolution Criteria
This inquiry will be considered affirmative if both of the following conditions are satisfied:
(a) There exists a span of at least 12 continuous months before the conclusion of 2120 during which no public US stock exchanges are operational for trading.
(b) All of the subsequent conditions are fulfilled before January 1, 2031:
- The Insurrection Act is enforced.
- During the enforcement of the Insurrection Act, a minimum of 500 fatalities occur within a 6 month timeframe due to armed confrontations between US citizens and a segment of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts among such entities.
- All of these fatalities take place in any US state(s) (including DC).
Fine Print
For condition (a), we will refer to the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):
The stock market encompasses the array of markets and exchanges where the routine activities of buying, selling, and issuing shares of publicly-held companies occur.
For condition (b), any confrontations between the US military and the armed forces of another nation will not be taken into account in this question. Confrontations involving the US military and US citizens, possibly aided by foreign nations with weapons or resources, will be included.
Engagements between civilians and local law enforcement will not be considered, unless there are active military forces in the area providing mutual assistance.
Fatalities are counted across all states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. Newly admitted states will be included, while states that secede or are removed will not be counted. Suicides are excluded from the death tally.
current_date: 2024-07-20 20:30:04.814869
kwargs: {'model': 'gpt-4o-mini'}
options: {'model': 'gpt-4o-mini', 'temperature': 0.5, 'response_model': <class 'common.datatypes.VerificationResult'>}

In particular:\n   - In case of events that happen at a fixed time (e.g. "Will France win the FIFA World Cup in 2026"), it should *never* be *before* the date when the event is scheduled to happen. Ideally it is exactly at the date. There can be *at most a month of leeway* to account for resolution issues and delays. If the delay is too long, the question should be marked invalid.\n   - In case of events that could resolve at an uncertain date (will Warren Buffet die of cancer?), the resolution date should be such that it is highly likely the event will happen before it. In this case, the `body` should say the question resolves N/A if the resolution date comes and there was no resolution.\n\n- The resolution criteria should not be excessively vague or ambiguous, and should be consistent with the question.\n\nThe format of your response should be:\nreasoning: [reasoning here]\nvalid: [True/False]\n\nExample 1:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2020?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected as the president of the United States before January 1, 2020.\nresolution_date: 2020-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body (resolution criteria) is clear and consistent with the title.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 2:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if it happens.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The body is too vague.\nvalid: False\n\n\nExample 3:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States before January 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2030.\nresolution_date: 2030-01-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution criteria are clear and consistent with the title.\nThe resolution date is consistent with the title and in the future.\nvalid: True\n\n\nExample 4:\ntitle: Will Kanye West become the president of the United States by 2030?\nbody: This question will resolve as Yes if Kanye West is elected and inaugurated as the president of the United States before January 1, 2031.\nresolution_date: 2031-12-01 00:00:00\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is too late compared to when the body says the question will resolve. The AI system must be a primary factor in the disruption, as opposed to a contributing technology among others. The industry in question must be one of the following: healthcare, automotive, finance, entertainment, or energy. Disruption is considered significant if it leads to a change in at least 20%% of the market share within the industry or a comparable metric of impact, such as a 20%% increase in efficiency or productivity. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, the French national football team (senior, not youth or women\'s) has won either the FIFA World Cup or the UEFA European Championship.\nresolution_date: 2026-12-31 23:59:59\n\n->\n\nreasoning: The resolution date is fine. The body is clear; there are multiple distinct pathways to resolution, but all are important for the question. The body includes a bit of background information that is not necessary for the question, but it is not harmful.\nvalid: True\n-----\n\ntitle: Is it possible that both of the following events happen: (a) A complete year passes without any open stock exchanges in the US by the year 2120 and (b) The United States experiences a second civil war prior to 2031?\nbody: Resolution Criteria\nThis inquiry will be considered affirmative if both of the following conditions are satisfied:\n(a) There exists a span of at least 12 continuous months before the conclusion of 2120 during which no public US stock exchanges are operational for trading.\n(b) All of the subsequent conditions are fulfilled before January 1, 2031:\n- The Insurrection Act is enforced.\n- During the enforcement of the Insurrection Act, a minimum of 500 fatalities occur within a 6 month timeframe due to armed confrontations between US citizens and a segment of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts among such entities.\n- All of these fatalities take place in any US state(s) (including DC).\nFine Print\nFor condition (a), we will refer to the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):\nThe stock market encompasses the array of markets and exchanges where the routine activities of buying, selling, and issuing shares of publicly-held companies occur.\nFor condition (b), any confrontations between the US military and the armed forces of another nation will not be taken into account in this question. Confrontations involving the US military and US citizens, possibly aided by foreign nations with weapons or resources, will be included.\nEngagements between civilians and local law enforcement will not be considered, unless there are active military forces in the area providing mutual assistance.\nFatalities are counted across all states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. Newly admitted states will be included, while states that secede or are removed will not be counted. Suicides are excluded from the death tally.\nresolution_date: 2119-12-31 00:00:00+00:00\n'}]

question.body: Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if (1) humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe, and (2) any exoplanet with more than 5% O2 atmosphere is found before January 1, 2030. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.
